11.06.text:
Coming up on @Issue:
You've heard about going green, but how does

13.84.text: this apply to the business world?

15.61.text:
Ryan Wolber from the Illinois Green Business
Association is here next to talk about how

19.68.text:
businesses all over the state are saving money
by becoming more eco-friendly.

25.20.text: What do you need to know to get started?

26.96.text: We'll find out next; @Issue starts right now.

32.03.text:
[Music Plays]
Welcome, and thanks for joining us for @Issue.

46.36.text:
The green movement has been around for a long
time now, but as that movement continues,

51.66.text: more facets of it also continue to emerge.

54.13.text: One of those facets is green business.

57.09.text:
Now, what does that mean, and how can it help
the environment?

60.21.text:
Well, here to answer that question is Ryan
Wolber, certification manager for the Illinois

66.81.text:
And you are here as part of the program through
the Charleston Chamber of Commerce.

70.33.text:
So, we thank you for stopping by the studio
to talk about green business.

73.81.text:
>>Ryan Wolber:
Thank you for having me.

75.07.text:
>>Lori Casey:
Well, Ryan, tell us a little bit about what

78.13.text:
>>Ryan Wolber:
Well, so the Illinois Green Business Association

83.20.text:
We focus on engaging businesses, on large
and small levels across the state, to really

88.31.text:
incorporate sustainability into their business
practices.

90.54.text: We do this through three main programs.

92.97.text:
We have our green business certification program,
which covers nine areas of business sustainability,

98.19.text:
from pollution prevention, to energy conservation,
water conservation, to even engaging the community.

103.29.text:
Our second program is our public engagement
aspect, along with education.

107.75.text:
That includes green drinks on a monthly basis
to engage community leaders and businesses

112.57.text: to our upcoming annual green business summit.

114.48.text:
That summit, our annual summit is really an
end of the year celebration, get-together

120.33.text:
event to talk about what were the successes,
what can we do to improve, and where is this

125.84.text:
And so, this year will be in Tinley Park,
October 15th.

127.69.text: It will be a great event.

130.18.text:
And that kind of wraps up our educational
aspect.

133.14.text:
Our third program is our direct installation
program.

135.92.text:
We partner with various utility companies,
Ameren Illinois, Nicor up in the Chicagoland,

142.03.text: suburb area, to install energy efficient equipment.

144.11.text:
We'll go into businesses, small, large, mostly
on a smaller scale, and do energy installations.

150.31.text:
That can be lighting upgrades, faucet aerators
that actually infuse a little bit of air jets

155.46.text:
into the water, streaming to make it a little
more efficient, water efficient.

160.00.text:
Both of those installations then have direct
financial savings for a business.

164.24.text:
So, those are the three main programs that
we as an organization reach through.

169.12.text:
So, now tell us where your offices are located
at.

173.12.text:
So, the IGB, we were founded eight years ago,
five years ago in 2008.

Three college students at the U of I got together,
they were doing off-campus recycling with

184.47.text:
And then, someone asked a question: why is
Green Street, the main street on campus, not

191.82.text:
And so, they started researching various business
programs, ways to engage communities and businesses,

198.07.text: to make them more environmentally friendly.

199.57.text:
And they found the California Green Business
program, based out in the San Francisco Bay

205.47.text:
And they've been in existence for about ten
years now, ten, fifteen years.

207.56.text:
And so, went out to California, worked with
them, collaborated, to then bring back a green

213.73.text: And that's where we're based out of: Urbana/Champaign.

And we still have our main offices there,
but then we have partnerships across the state

222.61.text:
So, you cover and travel to all the different
parts of the state.

226.28.text:
Yes, we're kind of all along the I-74 corridor,
Urbana/Champaign, Bloomington/Normal, Peoria,

Galesburg, Charleston, and the Eastern Illinois
University region, along with Oak Park River

239.90.text:
>>Lori Casey:
So, the whole idea started with some college

243.66.text:
>>Lori Casey:
Now, are they still involved in the project?

Yes, they're the three original founders.

We're a four-person staff, so I'm the new

that meet on a daily basis and really focus

Let's talk a little bit about how the term
'green' has evolved.

265.01.text:
When did it sort of start to become a little
more mainstream, and how has that term changed

270.32.text:

Well, I'd say the 'green' term started back

279.08.text:
But it really caught on in, I would definitely
say early 2000s, "Inconvenient Truth," Al

284.36.text:
Gore really led the charge and brought green
back to the mainstream.

289.20.text:
But in the last five years with the recession
and economic downturn, businesses were looking

293.33.text: for a way to cut costs.

294.81.text:
How can we improve our bottom line: increase
profits, increase revenue.

299.95.text:
And they found that being more resourceful,
more conservative with their resources, with

305.13.text:
energy usage and water usage, was a great
place to start.

308.42.text:
So, that is, I would say, the newest addition
of the green movement, is the more business

313.14.text: angle and being more efficient with your resources.

370.82.text:

381.54.text:

386.39.text:

391.78.text:
The next step is something people don't think

396.68.text:

412.55.text:
as many items out of the landfill; that can

And so, that's another way businesses can
